ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This class provides more insight on the systems of slavery present in the African World from a West African Perspective. It talks extensively about political systems and actors in Africa and how that affected slavery in their respective kindgom.
I learned so much about African history throughout the Atlantic slave trade. This class has also helped me develop my analytical skills with the final paper.
Ive seen a different perspective on the Atlantic slave trade. I
I learned about the slave trade in Africa, and the mechanisms in which it operated and the impacts it had on the continent
I certainly learned a lot about the Atlantic slave trade, as well as the politics and culture of West African societies during this period.
I learned much about African history and people and events I had not known about before.
I learned the history of a region of the world I had never previously studied. I learned how to compare and contrast by region and think critically about the history of Africa in the slave trade.
Essay writing skills, how to do multiple readings, speaking up in class.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Professor Harms just reads off the lecture slides, and by week 4 our class had shrunk from its original 30-person size to only 6-8 kids at the lecture. You didn't need to attend lectures and could still get an A in his course. He should change up his lecture pedagogy and format.

This class was good and really shined through with professor and teaching fellow. My only critique is there is no variability in the Prof's lecture. You could honestly skip lecture and read the slides before every section.

Professor Harms reads off the lecture slides word for word. Eventually, he uploaded the slides due to COVID. Still, the lectures felt incredibly pointless because everything he said was written in the slides. As a result, attending the lectures was hard because I felt that I could just look at the slides later.

Strengths: Interesting readings, Patrick was a great TF, workload wasn't too tough.
Weaknesses: Lectures themselves could be pretty dry

Interesting and easy to grasp content is a strength, but Professor Harms' lectures are often monotonous and dull leading to very low attendence since most of what he says can be garnered from the slides he reads off.
The class lecture was unenganging and unmotivating. Professor rarely deviated from lecture slides. However, the lecture content and readings were extremely interesting.
The class content is very interesting. The Professor just reads off of the slides, but it is still an enjoyable class.
It's a well organized course! I think if anything maybe less weight on the final.

One of the weaknesses is that an African studies class is being taught by a white man. Honestly, I do understand and respect that the course instructor is well versed in the topic but sometimes I would be seated in class as an African and gear him butcher the pronunciation of African names and cringe. Changing the professor would be too much to ask but it would be nice if the department was able to seek for African TAs who would bring the African touch to the class.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes

Yes if you want to learn the topics at hand. You're really judge on like 3 assignments + participation and you don't receive two of them back (final and final essay) so there wasn't to much growing based on feedback from the prof/teaching fellow.
No. I think that the knowledge I acquired in this class could be gained in a much more immersive way than in HIST 340. I felt that the lectures themselves were the weakness of the class.
Decently interesting and pretty gutty history course
Take the class for the content, recognizing that in-class lecture might not be the best
Yes, it is a great class about African history and you will learn a lot if you go to the lectures.
Yes, I would, for a good overview of West Africa during the slave trade with close looking at specific regions.
Yes, definitely! It was an amazing and informative class.
Yes. It was eye opening. No, if you would like a course with more student-teacher engagement

extras.title: AFST 340 01/HIST 340 01 - Africa in Era of Slave Trade
